Award.AwardTitle: Mossbauer and EPR Studies of Biological Oxygen Activation
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this award, the Chemistry of Life Processes Program in the Chemistry Division supports Dr. Eckard Munck from Carnegie Mellon University to conduct spectroscopic and theoretical studies of iron-containing enzymes and synthetic complexes that activate molecular oxygen. The studies involve characterization of reaction intermediates of the enzymes 2,3 homoprotocatechuate dioxygenase, 1,2 benzoate dioxygenase and methane monooxygenase; each of these proteins is a representative of a large class of enzymes that carry out catalytic reactions of fundamental importance. The studies focus on trapping short-lived (milliseconds) intermediates in high oxidations states such as iron(IV) and iron(V and involve low temperature Mossbauer and Electron Paramagnetic Resonance experiments, complemented by density functional theory calculations. Further studies are aimed at trapping putative iron(V) intermediates in water oxidation reactions, one of the great challenges in inorganic chemistry. Information gained from these investigations is expected to provide crucial insights into the mechanisms of high oxidation state chemistry.

Many catalytic reactions carried out by iron-containing enzymes in mammalian and bacterial organisms pass through states that contain as reactive species short-lived intermediates for which the iron atom is in an iron(IV) or iron(V) state bound to an oxo group derived from atmospheric oxygen. Mossbauer spectroscopy is a powerful tool to characterize these states in unprecedented detail. The spectra can be analyzed to yield a large number of parameters that characterize the oxidation state and the electronic structure of the iron. These parameters can be evaluated by quantum chemical methods to yield insights into the reactivity of these entities. Information gleaned from studies of the enzymes can be used by chemists to design synthetic complexes that either mimic the biological systems or perform functions that extend the range of the latter. The projects are carried out as collaborations between physicists, chemists and biochemists, providing training for graduate students and postdoctoral fellows of four collaborating groups as they acquire a broad perspective of an integrative approach to biological research. The research will be the basis of tutorial presentations to graduate students at Carnegie Mellon University, seven groups at the University of Minnesota as well to 70-80 graduate students at the 2014 Penn State Bioinorganic Workshop.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our research has focused on the study of oxygen activation in enzymes and bioinorganic complexes.  Funding of the present grant has resulted in 15 publications, all in top journals. In many iron containing enzymes molecular oxygen binds to the iron and becomes activated for catalysis. Among the many possible activated systems two have been of particular interest, namely formation of Fe(III)-superoxo and Fe(V)-oxo intermediates.

 Using Mossbauer and EPR spectroscopy as well as density functional theory (DFT) we have characterized a synthetic Fe(III)-superoxo complex; Stout et al. in Inorg. Chem. 2016, 55, 5216-26.   We have extracted an unprecedented amount of information from the well-resolved Mössbauer spectra which enabled us to obtain decisive information. Thus, the Mössbauer spectra show that the complex has system spin S = 3 which results from ferromagnetic coupling between the S= 5/2 spin of the Fe(III) and the spin S = ½ of the superoxo moiety. However, DFT analysis predicts that the coupling should be antiferromagnetic with a system spin S = 2. A theoretical model with spin-dependent electron transfer also predicts an S = 3 state. We have been tracking the failure of DFT theory to the so-called basis set superposition error inherent in such calculations when the bound oxygen moiety can interact with hydrogen atoms of the ligand. This result has importance for many problems in oxygen activation chemistry.

 In 2015 we published a report describing a synthetic iron complex, X, based on the ligand PyNMe3, of unprecedented hydrogen and oxygen transfer reactivity. Complex X is created by reacting an iron precursor, (PyNMe3)Fe(II) with a peracid (Py = pyridine). The report demonstrated that two reaction intermediates were in rapid equilibrium in solution. One of the intermediates was shown to be a diiro(III)-acylperoxo complex. We speculated the other intermediate to be an iron(V)-oxo species but could not prove the case as the reaction produced other species which masked the Mossbauer spectra. By modifying the reactions conditions we have now succeeded in determining its oxidation state by using a variety of spectroscopic techniques, supported by DFT calculations. The intermediate, indeed, is an iron(V)-oxo species. The DFT structures show that one of the oxygens of a peracid-derived carboxylate is only 2 Å away from the oxo group.. This unusual geometry is responsible for rapid reversible O-O bond cleavage and formation, shuttling between an Fe(III)-peroxo and an Fe(V)-oxo state, and is also a major contribution to the high reactivity. A manuscript by R. Fan et al. has been submitted to the Journal of the American Chemical Society.

 


Last Modified: 10/26/2017
Modified by: Eckard Munck
